title: The Mere Exposure Effect in Speaking
description: Learn The Mere Exposure Effect in Speaking in one minute.

hook.text: The more familiar something feels, the more we trust it â€” even if we can't explain why.

buildup.text: Robert Zajonc's mere exposure effect shows that repeated exposure breeds preference and trust.

discovery.text: In speaking, repetition of key phrases makes ideas feel true. Say it three times and it sticks.

twist.text: This is why politicians repeat slogans. Familiarity doesn't mean truth â€” but the brain treats it that way.

climax.text: Ethical speakers use repetition for clarity. Manipulative ones use it as a shortcut to false trust.

punchline.text: Repetition doesn't make things true. It makes them feel true.
